title: Teen adoptee catfished by woman claiming she placed her baby for adoption
text:
"Callie messaged me because I was adopted. She quickly became my best friend. But now her voice was coming out of someone I didn’t recognise."

There are currently 50,000 Australian children living in foster care and their chance of being adopted is less than one per cent. To mark National Adoption Awareness Month, Adopt Change CEO Renee Carter is calling for red tape to be cut so children can be more easily placed in a permanent home. Ms Carter says the foster care system can be ‘really damaging’ for children, with some moving up to 70 times, ‘so really it’s just not good enough’.

“I know this is weird because you don’t really know me … But you are adopted, right?”

Of all the messages Callie could have sent, this was the one Hannah was powerless to ignore.

The American teenager was extremely open about the fact that she had been adopted and felt excited to share her story with someone in need.

Callie said she had placed her son up for adoption just days earlier and wanted to make sure she had made the right choice.

“My heart ached for this girl, as she opened up to me about her experience placing her son and the backlash she experienced from friends and family leading up to her decision,” Hannah first wrote on Love What Matters.

“She wanted to know how I felt about my birth parents having grown up knowing I was placed. I love them, and I told her that.

“She asked more questions about my relationship and found hope in the positive nature of my experience.”

Hannah was just 17 when she was first contacted by Callie. Source: Hannah Jennings

"How did you find me?"

Hannah also asked how Callie had come to find her Instagram account.

She couldn’t believe it when Callie said she had found a song Hannah had written for her birth mum ‘Right Thing.’

At the time, Callie had been struggling with whether she wanted to keep her baby and she said the song had helped her make the right decision.

“She said she would listen to that song over and over until she decided that adoption would be the best option for her and her baby,” Hannah explained.

“She continued to listen to my song as she poured over hopeful adoptive parent profiles.

“‘Right Thing’ was the only thing that gave her the strength to go through with signing papers the day she did.”

Callie wanted to know if Hannah knew her birth parents. Source: Hannah Jennings

“It was so cool to call Callie"

Hannah and Callie continued to talk and quickly realised they had more in common than just adoption.

They were both 17, loved playing football and had heaps of the same interests.

Soon enough Hannah was basically glued to her phone 24/7 messaging Callie.

“It’s crazy how a simple Q&A session that first evening escalated pretty quickly into what I considered to be one of my best friendships,” she said.

“We eventually ditched Instagram and exchanged phone numbers. It was so cool to call Callie. We talked often and for a long time.

“We sent pictures back and forth and I was able to see pictures she would get from her baby’s parents. He was such a doll.”

Eventually, Hannah's parents got to know Callie as well. Source: Hannah Jennings

"Callie started talking to my mum as well"

But Hannah quickly realised that Callie’s life was complicated, even after her baby was successfully adopted.

Her mum fell pregnant and then miscarried a baby that wasn’t her husband’s, Callie crashed her car and also had to have an emergency appendectomy.

Hannah supported her friend through it all, even though they had never met in person.

“She told me if it weren’t for me, she wasn’t sure if she would still be here,” Hannah said.

“At some point, Callie started talking to my mum as well,” she said.

“They would talk on the phone too, probably longer on the phone than I had with her.

“Callie confided in my mum a lot of things. It almost felt like with so much chaos in her own home-life, she found solace talking to my mum.”

Eventually, details in Callie's story didn't add up. Source: Hannah Jennings

"We came to an unbelievable realisation"

But as the months went by, both Hannah and her mum realised that details in Callie’s stories didn’t quite add up.

In the end, they called Callie’s high school to check if she actually went there.

“We came to an unbelievable realisation: Callie was not a real person,” Hannah said.

“We confronted her and told her we knew she wasn’t who she said she was. She asked us not to be angry, and we asked for answers.

“She wasn’t Callie. She wasn’t 17. The pictures she had sent us of her weren’t really her, and the pictures of her baby weren’t really her baby.

“She was a 26-year-old woman who hadn’t placed a baby up for adoption, but had just wanted to know more and didn’t know how else to.

“She told us how she had genuinely come to know and love our family, and that’s why this relationship lasted as many months as it had.”

Hannah's mum did everything she could think of to cheer her up. Source: Hannah Jennings

"It was her voice"

The news hit Hannah hard, she could barely get out of bed and struggled to get through each day.

Her body physically ached and she found it hard to even fake a smile.

“My mum did what she thought was best, and emailed the address ‘Callie’ had given us.

“She explained how much pain I was in, and asked that if she meant it that she had genuinely grown to love our family, then she would FaceTime us and let us see her real face.

“She came up on the screen and looked nothing like the girl we had received pictures of for months. But that was her voice.

“It was surreal to hear the voice we had talked hours to, but coming out of someone we didn’t recognise. She apologised profusely.

"That conversation brought me closure and helped me to start to pick up my pieces."

Follow Hannah's journey on Instagram.

Hannah finally got the closure that she needed. Source: Hannah Jennings
